title: I am glad I come to this section
body:
I use to be that girl who always said: "I am not toxic, I just respond to everyone bm'ing me so I am not at fault."

But now that I see that EVERY salty person says this, and then see their chat logs. I see how dumb that comes across and it really helps me just use the mute button and report trolls/toxic players after the game.

replies.body: I came to this same conclusion lately as well.  "Defending yourself" gets no where.  Better to mute them and try to be positive to your other teammates (as they are probably still hearing the toxic player and haven't muted them).

Speaking from my own perspective here, but when under attack over a play, I try to roll my eyes more often than launching some kind of return salvo. Ultimately, responding just gets me into an argument on the internet, which is like, the worst. If I can get to a place where I can roll my eyes and move on, I'm in much better mental shape to actually win the game. 

Then again I was losing lane last night when my opponent asked if I was actually Plat last season. That did motivate me to a 16/3/10 win. ^.^

Players who look at your name and do mental gymnastics to take bronze with a melodramatic floor routine aren't players worth the time to think about when considering the name.

I named this account this name purposefully to root out the positive from the toxic and negative -- It's a salt bait, you see.

If anything goes wrong or you have a conversation they don't agree with, you're somehow instantly toxic to them;

Anything goes right and either they or the enemy don't like it -- You're suddenly a boosted animal, or a smurf who can't win their own ELO who has to rely on X tactic or X champion in order to win.

Being a smurf, or good, or a girl playing an account with a name designed to tilt your enemy/ counter-bait the flamebaiters on your team won't stop the inevitable assumptions based on a summoner name.

People are entitled to informed opinions, not base assumption opinions. No one's entitled to act a fool;

And from experience, you're going to see alot who see the name and will start hopping like you just popped in Kris Kross's "Jump".

Because what people say via keyboard to another person is sooooo damaging. Cyber bullying is an illusion brought on by weak minded little bitches. Oh someone said something bad about you in a video game/on facebook? That sucks, at least you have access to those luxuries you ingrate.

The online world is an extension of many people's daily lives. There is no reason for anyone to behave as you do online, let alone in person.

I don't care what you call it, "cyberbullying" "flaming" "toxicity", none of the behaviours encompassed by those terms is appropriate in a game, a workplace, a place of education, or anywhere for that matter.
First world problems are pretty cute.

Congratulations, you've discovered the internet.

Go back to your bridge.

Not a troll, just a scorned player who has to deal with feeders. You will feel my digital wrath via keyboard, or not. The choice to be offended is yours. I've said this countless times and no one seems to understand.... how you play can be way more toxic then anything you can ever say in chat. Who would you hate more, the 0/12 player who doesn't flame or the person who has to deal with him that does? Keep in mind in this circumstance the flaming player is trying to win and is doing good.

Are you claiming that feeders aren't being punished?

http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/Alrhftbk-first-time-ban-immediately-14-days-next-time-permaban

Here you go. This is the figurative "0/12" guy. First offense. 14 day ban. Second offense and he will get a permanent ban.

Edit: Flaming as retaliation is never appropriate.

I refuse to be a silent victim. If that means getting in trouble at least I stood up for myself and let them know I won't stand for that shit. 

Here's a nice example. You see someone getting harassed by a group of bullies and help him out by throwing some flak at them. It's successful. They back off, but instead of them getting punished you do, for having "said some mean things and hurting peoples feelings." How about having ironclad feelings and not being phased by someone attacking you from behind a keyboard? Do my words hurt you? Do they cause you physical, mental, or emotional pain? If so I think you need some help because I've gone through some horrible shit in real life and it makes the things I've said in retaliation tame by comparison.

I don't know if the two players in my game who fed got punished. I don't know if they ever will.

Report them and move on.

You gain nothing by flaming them back. Nothing, except for the repercussions of your own actions.

All of this:
> How about having ironclad feelings and not being phased by someone attacking you from behind a keyboard? Do my words hurt you? Do they cause you physical, mental, or emotional pain? If so I think you need some help because I've gone through some horrible shit in real life and it makes the things I've said in retaliation tame by comparison.

What gives you the right to go out and practice violence upon others? Just because you've had a "hard" life?

No. You don't know who is on the other side of that monitor, what they have been through, or are currently going through.

You are not entitled to harass, abuse, or attack others just because you have been harassed, abused, or attacked.

Good luck in life, seems like you will need it.

The way I see it, intentional feeders already know they are there to ruin the game for other players. They don't care what you say, they're there to ruin YOUR day. So by retaliating, you're not helping anyone and that can only get you into trouble.

Unintentional feeders, on the other hand....Maybe they are having a bad day, maybe learning a new champion/trying a new build, maybe they are just plain bad. Either way, harassing them is not helping anyone. On the contrary, it could distract them and make them perform even worse, which is counter productive. Best thing is to give constructive criticism, some encouragement when they did do something right, or just not say anything. Heck, if you really want to, yell at your screen and let your frustration out. At least that way it won't affect anyone else in the game.

I can see why someone would be toxic to another toxic player, but I don't think that's the best course of action either. Similarly to the intentional feeder case, if they want to harass you and make your day worse, then they don't care what you say. If you retaliate, that just mean you're not focusing on the game, which could affect the outcome of the game. Instead of a 4v5 with a monkey constantly in their ear, your teammates will have to fight a 3v5 while you two are arguing over nothing. If they say you're bad, show them wrong. Action speaks louder than words.
